{{featured article}} {{Infobox military person | name = Henry Hoʻolulu Pitman | image = Henry Hoolulu Pitman, Peabody Essex Museum.jpg | image_size = 250 | alt = | caption = Portrait of Henry Hoʻolulu Pitman at the [[Peabody Essex Museum]] | birth_date = {{Birth date|1845|3|18}} | birth_place = [[Hilo, Hawaii|Hilo]], [[Hawaii (island)|Hawaiʻi]], [[Kingdom of Hawaii|Kingdom of Hawaiʻi]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|mf=yes|1863|2|27|1845|3|18}} | death_place = [[Parole, Maryland|Parole Camp]], [[Annapolis, Maryland]] | placeofburial = [[Mount Auburn Cemetery]], [[Cambridge, Massachusetts]] | placeofburial_coordinates = | allegiance = [[United States|United States of America]]
[[Union (American Civil War)|Union]] | branch = [[Union Army]] | serviceyears = 1862–63 | rank = [[Private (rank)|Private]] | unit = [[22nd Regiment Massachusetts Volunteer Infantry]] | commands = | battles = [[American Civil War]] *[[Maryland Campaign]] *[[Battle of Antietam]] *[[Battle of Shepherdstown]] | memorials = | relations = [[Benjamin Pitman (Hawaii)|Benjamin Pitman]] and [[Kinooleoliliha|Kinoʻoleoliliha]] (parents) }} '''Timothy Henry Hoʻolulu Pitman''' (March 18, 1845 – February 27, 1863) was an American [[Union Army]] soldier of [[Native Hawaiians|Native Hawaiian]] descent. Considered one of the "Hawaiʻi Sons of the Civil War", he was among a group of more than one hundred documented Native Hawaiian and Hawaii-born combatants who fought in the [[American Civil War]] while the [[Kingdom of Hawaii|Kingdom of Hawaiʻi]] was still an independent nation. Born and raised in [[Hilo, Hawaii|Hilo, Hawaiʻi]], he was the eldest son of [[Kinooleoliliha|Kinoʻoleoliliha]], a Hawaiian high chiefess, and [[Benjamin Pitman (Hawaii)|Benjamin Pitman]], an American pioneer settler from [[Massachusetts]]. Through his father's business success in the whaling and sugar and coffee plantation industries and his mother's familial connections to the Hawaiian royal family, the Pitmans were quite prosperous and owned lands on the [[Hawaii (island)|island of Hawaiʻi]] and in [[Honolulu]]. He and his older sister were educated in the mission schools in Hilo alongside other children of mixed Hawaiian descent. After the death of his mother in 1855, his father remarried to the widow of a missionary, thus connecting the family to the American missionary community in Hawaiʻi. However, following the deaths of his first wife and later his second wife, his father decided to leave the islands and returned to Massachusetts with his family around 1860. He continued his education in the public schools of [[Roxbury, Boston|Roxbury]], where the Pitman family lived for a period of time. Leaving school without his family's knowledge, he made the decision to fight in the Civil War in August 1862. Despite his mixed-race ancestry, Pitman avoided the racial segregation imposed on other Native Hawaiian recruits of the time and enlisted in the [[22nd Regiment Massachusetts Volunteer Infantry]], a white regiment. He served as a [[Private (rank)|private]] in the Union Army fighting in the [[Battle of Antietam]] and the [[Maryland Campaign]]. In his company, Private [[Robert G. Carter]] befriended the part-Hawaiian soldier and wrote in later life of their common experience in the 22nd Massachusetts. Compiled decades afterward from old letters, Carter's account described the details surrounding his final fate in the war. On the march to [[Battle of Fredericksburg|Fredericksburg]], Pitman was separated from his regiment and captured by Confederate guerrilla forces. He was forced to march to [[Richmond, Virginia|Richmond]] and incarcerated in the Confederate [[Libby Prison]], where he contracted "lung fever" from the harsh conditions of his imprisonment and died on February 27, 1863, a few months after his release on parole in a prisoner exchange. Modern historians consider Henry Hoʻolulu Pitman to be the only known Hawaiian or [[Pacific Islander]] to die as a prisoner of war in the Civil War.{{sfn|Vance|Manning|2015b|pages=146–149}}{{sfn|Grzyb|2016|pages=127–128}} For a period of time after the end of the war, the legacy and contributions of Pitman and other documented Hawaiian participants in the American Civil War were largely forgotten except in the private circles of descendants and historians. However, there has been a revival of interest in recent years in the Hawaiian community. In 2010, these "Hawaiʻi Sons of the Civil War" were commemorated with a bronze plaque erected along the memorial pathway at the [[National Memorial Cemetery of the Pacific]] in Honolulu.{{cite news|last=Cole|first=William|title=Native Hawaiians served on both sides during Civil War|url=http://the.honoluluadvertiser.com/article/2010/May/31/ln/hawaii5310346.html|date=May 31, 2010|newspaper=Honolulu Star-Advertiser|location=Honolulu|publisher=Oahu Publications, Inc.|accessdate=August 5, 2015}}{{sfn|Vance|Manning|2015b|pages=146–149}} ==Early life and family== [[File:'Hilo from the Bay', oil on canvas painting by James Gay Sawkins, 1852,.jpg|thumbnail|left|300px|''Hilo from the Bay'', oil on canvas painting by [[James Gay Sawkins]], 1852]] Timothy Henry Hoʻolulu Pitman{{#tag:ref|His name is given in various ways in the sources.{{sfn|Vance|Manning|2015b|pages=146–149}} On one side of the Pitman family grave marker at [[Mount Auburn Cemetery]] is inscribed "Timothy Henry Pitman", and his enlistment records list him under "Timothy H. Pitman".{{sfn|Parker|Carter|1887|page=572}} In the [[1860 United States Census]], his name is recorded as "Henry Pitman".{{cite web|title=1860 United States Census|url=http://www.mocavo.com/Henry-Pitman-B1845-Newton-Middlesex-Massachusetts-1860-United-States-Census/01754860596728994882|website=[[Mocavo]]|registration=yes|accessdate=September 6, 2015}} In Hawaiʻi, his name was written as "T. Henry Pitman" in the ''Annual Report of the Hawaiian Mission Children's Society'', as "Henry Pitman" in his English obituary in ''The Pacific Commercial Advertiser'' and as "Henry Hoolulu Pitman (Pikimana)" in the Hawaiian newspaper ''Ka Nupepa Kuokoa''.{{sfn|Hawaiian Mission Children's Society|1863|page=35}}{{cite news|title=Na Mea Hou O Hawaii Nei – Keiki Kupa|newspaper=Ka Nupepa Kuokoa|location=Honolulu|publisher=|date=May 30, 1863|volume=II|number=22|page=2|url=http://papakilodatabase.com/pdnupepa/cgi-bin/pdnupepa?a=d&d=KNK18630530-01.1.2|accessdate=August 5, 2015}}|group=note}} was born March 18, 1845, in [[Hilo, Hawaii|Hilo, Hawaiʻi]], the first son and second child of [[Benjamin Pitman (Hawaii)|Benjamin Pitman]] and [[Kinooleoliliha|Kinoʻoleoliliha]].{{sfn|Kai|1974|page=64}}{{sfn|Pitman|1931|pages=149–154}}{{#tag:ref|Sources differ on his birth year.{{sfn|Vance|Manning|2015b|pages=146–149}} Historian Peggy Kai presents 1843 as his birth year.{{sfn|Kai|1974|page=64}} The Pitman family marker at Mount Auburn gives March 18, 1845, as his birth date, with the age of death as seventeen years, 11 months, and 9 days. His obituary in Boston's ''Evening Saturday Gazette'' stated his age was seventeen years, 11 months, and 7 days. The Honolulu newspaper ''The Pacific Commercial Advertiser'' stated he was about twenty years of age when he died.|group=note}} Originally a native of [[Salem, Massachusetts]], Pitman's father was an early pioneer, businessman and sugar and coffee plantation owner on the island of [[Hawaii (island)|Hawaiʻi]], who profited greatly from the kingdom's booming whaling industry in the early 1800s.{{sfn|Merry|2000|pages=156–163}}{{sfn|Kuykendall|1965|pages=307–310}} On his father's side, he was a great-grandson of Joshua Pitman (1755–1822), an English-American carpenter on the ship ''Franklin'' under Captain Allen Hallett during the [[American Revolutionary War]].{{sfn|Daughters of the American Revolution|1938|page=274}}{{sfn|Massachusetts|1904|page=445}} On his mother's side, Pitman was a descendant of [[Kameʻeiamoku]], one of the royal twins (with [[Kamanawa]]) who advised [[Kamehameha I]] in his conquest of the [[Hawaiian Islands]], and also of the early American or English sea captain Harold Cox, who lent his name to [[Keeaumoku II|George "Cox" Kahekili Keʻeaumoku II]], the [[Governor of Maui]].{{sfn|Pitman|1931|pages=149–154}}{{sfn|McKinzie|1983|pages=46–47}}{{cite news|title=Ancient Hawaiian Lineage in Bostonian Coming Today|newspaper=Honolulu Star-Bulletin|location=Honolulu|publisher=Oahu Publications, Inc.|date=January 30, 1917|volume=XXIV|issue=7737|page=10|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82014682/1917-01-30/ed-1/seq-10/|accessdate=August 5, 2015}}{{cite news|title=Mookuauhau Alii – Na Iwikuamoo o Hawaii Nei Mai Kahiko Mai|newspaper=Ka Makaainana|location=Honolulu|publisher=|date=August 3, 1896|volume=VI|number=5|page=2|url=http://hawaiiankingdom.org/pdf/Aug_3_1896.pdf|accessdate=August 5, 2015}}{{Hawaiian Dictionaries|Peleuli II Brought Up In Kamehamehaʻs Court|dic=maui|id=D0.5.16|accessdate=August 5, 2015}} Henry Hoʻolulu Pitman shared his [[Hawaiian name]] with his maternal grandfather [[Hoolulu|Hoʻolulu]], who, along with his brother [[Hoapili]], helped conceal the bones of King Kamehameha I in a secret hiding place after his death.{{sfn|Kuykendall|1965|page=63}} In the [[Hawaiian language]], the name "Hoʻolulu" means "to lie in the sheltered waters".{{sfn|Pukui|Elbert|Mookini|1974|page=52}} His siblings were Mary Ann Pitman Ailau (1838–1905), Benjamin Keolaokalani Franklin Pitman (1852–1918) and half-sister Maria Kinoʻole Pitman Morey (1858–1892).{{sfn|Hawaiian Mission Children's Society|1863|page=35}}{{sfn|Pitman|1931|pages=149–154}}{{sfn|Walworth|1897|page=96}}{{cite news|title=Death of an Old Kamaaina|newspaper=Hilo Tribune|location=Hilo, HI|publisher=Hilo Tribune Publishing Company|date=February 14, 1905|volume=10|issue=16|page=1|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82016339/1905-02-14/ed-1/seq-1/|accessdate=August 5, 2015}} Because of his father's success in business and his mother's descent from Hawaiian royalty, the Pitman family was considered quite prosperous and were host to the royal family when they visited Hilo.{{sfn|Pitman|1931||page=20}}{{sfn|Kanahele|1999|page=76}} Besides being one of the leading merchants in town, his father also served the government as district magistrate of Hilo. Henry's mother, Kinoʻole, had inherited control over much of the lands in Hilo and Ōlaʻa from her own father, and King [[Kamehameha III]] had granted her use of the ''[[ahupuaa|ahupuaʻa]]'' of Hilo after her marriage.{{sfn|Pitman|1931||page=20}} During Henry's early childhood, the family lived in the mansion that Benjamin Pitman had built in 1840, in an area known as Niopola, one of the favored resort spots of [[ancient Hawaii]]an royalty. The residence also became known as the Spencer House after Pitman sold it to his business partner Captain Thomas Spencer.{{#tag:ref|During the [[American Civil War]], Captain Thomas Spencer personally funded and drilled a company of infantry composed mostly of [[Native Hawaiians]] from Hilo. These volunteers, dubbed the "Spencer's Invincibles", offered their services to President [[Abraham Lincoln|Lincoln]] and the [[Union (American Civil War)|Union]]. However, in order to avert diplomatic controversy and in defense of the Hawaiʻi's neutrality, King [[Kamehameha IV]] and Minister [[Robert Crichton Wyllie]] officially denied permission for the men to go as a unit.{{sfn|Dye|1997||page=77}}{{sfn|Vance|Manning|2015a|pages=134–135}}{{cite news|last=Damon|first=Ethel M.|title=Punahou Volunteers of 1863|newspaper=The Friend|location=Honolulu|publisher=|date=April 1, 1941|volume=CXI|issue=4|page=67|url=http://server.honstudios.com/mhm-friend/cgi-bin/mhm-friend?a=d&d=Friend19410401-01.2.5&cl|accessdate=August 5, 2015}} When Captain Spencer heard the news, he reportedly burst into tears.{{sfn|Daws|1968||page=183}}|group=note}} The property later became the site of the Hilo Hotel, built in 1888 and torn down in 1956.{{harvnb|O'Connor|1997|pages=208–213}}; {{harvnb|Pierce|1956|pages=20–30}}; {{cite news|title=Returning Home After Fifty Years|newspaper=Honolulu Star-Bulletin|location=Honolulu|publisher=Oahu Publications, Inc.|date=December 26, 1916|volume=XXIV|issue=7707|page=9|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82014682/1916-12-26/ed-1/seq-9/|accessdate=August 5, 2015}}{{#tag:ref|During a trip to Hawaiʻi in 1917, Almira Hollander Pitman, his sister-in-law, wrote "The hotel in Hilo is the old home of the Pitmans, and Dad [Benjamin Keolaokalani Franklin Pitman] remembered it all. Of course the old garden is nearly gone, and houses are built on the grounds, but many of the old trees are still growing."{{sfn|Pitman|1931||pages=74–75}}|group=note}} In the 1850s the family moved to the capital of [[Honolulu]] where Benjamin Pitman took up banking and built a beautiful two-story house that he named Waialeale ("rippling water") at the corner of Alakea and Beretania Streets.{{sfn|Pitman|1931||page=20}} ==Education== [[File:Mary Ann and Henry Hoolulu Pitman.jpg|thumbnail|right|225px|Portrait of Henry and his sister Mary at the [[Peabody Essex Museum]]]] While in Hawaiʻi, Pitman and his older sister Mary attended Mrs. Wetmore's children's school in Hilo. The school was located at the Wetmores' residence on Church Street. Taught by Lucy Sheldon Taylor Wetmore, the wife of American missionary doctor and government physician Charles Hinckley Wetmore, the two elder Pitman children received their education in English rather than Hawaiian. This was unusual since Hawaiian was the official language of the Kingdom of Hawaiʻi, and all other schools in Hilo were conducted in the Hawaiian language. Mrs. Wetmore taught the children reading, writing, spelling, arithmetic and singing, while also reinforcing the curriculum with a strong adherence to the principles of the [[Protestantism|Protestant faith]]. Like the Pitman siblings, many of their classmates were also of half-Hawaiian (''hapa-kanaka'') descent with a majority of them being [[Chinese immigration to Hawaii|Chinese-Hawaiians]] (''hapa-pake'').{{sfn|Kai|1974|pages=62–64}}{{sfn|Merry|2000|pages=174–175}} After the death of his mother Kinoʻole in 1855, Pitman's father remarried to Maria Louisa Walsworth Kinney, the widow of American missionary Rev. Henry Kinney. The Kinneys were part of the Twelfth Company of missionaries from the [[American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions]] to arrive in 1848. The marriage aligned the Pitman children with the American missionary community. They were called "cousins" by the children of the missionaries and considered part of the extended missionary family of Hawaiʻi.{{sfn|Hawaiian Mission Children's Society|1863|page=35}}{{sfn|Manning|Vance|2014|pages=161–162}}{{sfn|Hawaiian Mission Children's Society|1901|pages=86, 88}} This first stepmother died in 1858 after giving birth to their father's fourth child, a daughter named Maria Kinoʻole (1858–1892).{{sfn|Walworth|1897|page=96}}{{sfn|Hawaiian Mission Children's Society|1901|page=88}} The Pitman family returned to Massachusetts in 1860 where his father remarried to his third wife Martha Ball, giving his four children another stepmother.{{harvnb|Pitman|1931||page=21}}; {{harvnb|Merry|2000|page=156}}; {{cite news|last=Wood|first=Ben|title=Museum given manuscript of early Hilo businessman|newspaper=Honolulu Star-Bulletin|location=Honolulu|publisher=Oahu Publications, Inc.|date=March 17, 2007|volume=12|issue=76|url=http://archives.starbulletin.com/2007/03/17/features/wood.html|accessdate=August 5, 2015}} According to an 1887 biography written by [[Robert G. Carter]], a private who would later serve in the same company as Pitman, he was neglected after his mother's death by his father and stepmother, who "subjected [him] to neglect and treatment, that with his sensitive nature he could not bear".{{sfn|Parker|Carter|1887|pages=215–216}} He continued his education in the public schools of [[Roxbury, Boston|Roxbury]], where the Pitman family lived for a period of time.{{sfn|Carter|1897|pages=139–142}}{{sfn|Carter|1913|pages=139–142}} The [[1860 United States Census]] registered Pitman under his teacher Solomon Adams as residing and presumably being educated in [[Newton, Massachusetts|Newton]], also in the Boston area. Growing into adolescence, he was said to strongly resemble his Hawaiian mother.{{sfn|Parker|Carter|1887|pages=215–216}} Robert G. Carter gave a brief description of his appearance in wartime letters first published in 1897:{{#tag:ref|The description, along with one of the only detailed accounts of Henry Hoʻolulu Pitman's service in the Civil War, was originally written in a letter by an unnamed member of the artillery unit of the 22nd Regiment.{{sfn|Vance|Manning|2015b|pages=146–149}} [[Robert G. Carter]] compiled this and other letters in the 1870s. It was first published serially in the ''Maine Bugle'' from 1896 to 1898. In 1913 Carter published the whole work in his book ''Four Brothers in Blue, Or, Sunshine and Shadows of the War of the Rebellion: A Story of the Great Civil War from Bull Run to Appomattox.''{{sfn|Carter|1913|pages=vii, 204–206}}|group=note}}
[A] tall, slim boy, straight as an arrow. His face was a perfect oval, his hair was as black as a raven's wing, and his eyes were large and of that peculiar soft, melting blackness,{{#tag:ref|His enlistment card indicated he had "hazel" or "gray" colored eyes.{{cite web|title=Enlistment Records for Timothy H. Pitman|url=https://www.fold3.com/image/524394254|work=Civil War Compiled Service Records|year=2014|publisher=The National Archives and Records Administration|location=Washington, DC|accessdate=August 5, 2015}}|group=note}} which excites pity when one is in distress. His skin was a clear, dark olive, bordering on the swarthy, and this, with his high cheek bones, would have led us to suppose that his nationality was different from our own, had we not known that his name was plain Henry P. There was an air of good breeding and refinement about him, that, with his small hands and feet, would have set us to thinking, had it not been that in our youth and intensely enthusiastic natures, we gave no thought to our comrades' personal appearance. We can look back now and see the shy, reserved nature of the boy, the dark, melancholy eyes, the sad smile, the sensitive twitching of the lips.{{sfn|Carter|1897|pages=139–142}}{{sfn|Carter|1913|pages=139–142}}
==American Civil War== After the outbreak of the [[American Civil War]], the [[Kingdom of Hawaii|Kingdom of Hawaiʻi]] under King [[Kamehameha IV]] declared its neutrality on August 26, 1861.{{sfn|Kuykendall|1953|pages=57–66}}{{sfn|Forbes|2001|pages=298–299}} But many [[Native Hawaiian]]s and Hawaiian-born Americans (mainly descendants of the American missionaries) both abroad and in the islands volunteered and enlisted in the military regiments of various states in the [[Union (American Civil War)|Union]] and the [[Confederate States of America|Confederacy]].{{sfn|Grzyb|2016|pages=127–128}} Individual Native Hawaiians had been serving in the United States Navy and Army since the [[War of 1812]], and even more served during the American Civil War.{{sfn|Schmitt|1998|pages=171–172}} Many Hawaiians sympathized with the Union because of Hawaiʻi's ties to [[New England]] through its missionaries and the whaling industries, and the ideological opposition of many to the institution of [[Slavery in the United States|slavery]].{{sfn|Manning|Vance|2014|pages=145–170}} ===Enlistment and service=== [[File:Timothy. H. Pitman, enlistment card.jpg|thumbnail|right|125px|Enlistment card for Henry Pitman]] On August 14, 1862, Pitman left school without his family's knowledge and volunteered to serve in the [[Union Army]] and fight in the American Civil War.{{sfn|Vance|Manning|2015b|pages=146–149}} He apparently never informed his family in advance about the choice to join the war because the news of his enlistment was reported back in Hawaiʻi's American missionary community as "Henry Pitman has run away from home and gone [to war]."{{sfn|Manning|Vance|2014|pages=161–162}} Carter described Pitman's rationale for enlisting: "In the midst of the clamor of war, when the very air vibrated with excitement, the wild enthusiasm of the crowds, and the inspiring sound of the drum, his Indian nature rose within him. His resolve was made."{{sfn|Parker|Carter|1887|pages=215–216}}{{sfn|Carter|1897|pages=139–142}}{{sfn|Carter|1913|pages=139–142}} Pitman was a ''[[Hapa|hapa-haole]]'', of part Hawaiian and part Caucasian descent.{{#tag:ref|Specifically, he was 3/8 Hawaiian and 5/8 Caucasian.|group=note}} His father was white and his native-born mother was also part Caucasian from her own mother, who was the daughter of Captain Cox and a Hawaiian chiefess.{{sfn|McKinzie|1983|pages=46–47}}{{sfn|Kai|1974|pages=62–64}} Despite his mixed-race ancestry, Pitman avoided the racial segregation imposed on other Native Hawaiian volunteers in this period. Most Native Hawaiians who participated in the war were assigned to [[United States Colored Troops|colored regiments]], but Pitman's fair skin color meant he was able to serve in a white unit, indicating that unit assignment may have been influenced by how dark Hawaiians appeared.{{sfn|Vance|Manning|2015b|pages=146–149}}{{cite journal|last1=Vance|first1=Justin W.|last2=Manning|first2=Anita|title=The Effects of the American Civil War on Hawaiʻi and the Pacific World|journal=World History Connected|volume=9|issue=3|year=October 2012|location=Champaign, IL|publisher=University of Illinois|url=http://worldhistoryconnected.press.illinois.edu/9.3/vance.html|accessdate=August 5, 2015}}{{#tag:ref|During the war, [[Samuel C. Armstrong]], the son of an American missionary in [[Maui]] who also enlisted, met two Native Hawaiians named [[J. R. Kealoha|Kealoha]] and Kaiwi, who were privates in the [[41st United States Colored Infantry|41st Regiment United States Colored Troops]] and [[28th Indiana Infantry Regiment (Colored)|28th Regiment United States Colored Troops]], respectively.{{sfn|Okihiro|2015|pages=88–89}}{{cite news|last=Armstrong|first=Samuel C.|authorlink=Samuel C. Armstrong|title=Extract of a Letter from Col. Armstrong|newspaper=The Friend|location=Honolulu|publisher=Samuel C. Damon|date=April 1, 1865|volume=22|issue=4|page=30|url=http://server.honstudios.com/mhm-friend/cgi-bin/mhm-friend?a=d&d=Friend18650401-01.2.12&cl|accessdate=August 5, 2015}}|group=note}} Historians Bob Dye, [[James L. Haley]] and others claimed Pitman was placed in the colored regiments because of his mixed race,{{sfn|Dye|1997||page=80}}{{sfn|Haley|2014|page=190}} but regiment records indicate otherwise.{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Jeffrey Allen|title=The Civil War and Hawaii|newspaper=The New York Times: Opinionator|location=New York|publisher=Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, Jr.|date=August 13, 2013|url=http://opinionator.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/08/13/the-civil-war-and-hawaii/?_r=0|accessdate=August 5, 2015}} Pitman served as a private in the [[22nd Regiment Massachusetts Volunteer Infantry]], Company H.{{cite web|title=Soldier Details|url=http://www.nps.gov/civilwar/search-soldiers-detail.htm?soldierId=ff3c82c3-dc7a-df11-bf36-b8ac6f5d926a|work=Shively|accessdate=July 25, 2014}}{{sfn|Parker|Carter|1887|page=572}}{{sfn|Massachusetts|1931|page=696}} This regiment was also named the "Henry Wilson's Regiment" after Col. [[Henry Wilson]], who commanded the unit in 1861. Col. [[William S. Tilton]] was the commander during Pitman's brief term of service. The regiment was part of the [[V Corps (Union Army)|V Corps]] of the [[Army of the Potomac]] under the command of [[Major general (United States)|Major General]] [[George B. McClellan]]. During this period, the regiment fought in the [[Second Battle of Bull Run]]{{sfn|Vance|Manning|2015b|pages=146–149}} and was involved in the [[Maryland Campaign]] fighting in the [[Battle of Antietam]], the bloodiest single-day battle in American history, and the [[Battle of Shepherdstown]].{{sfn|Parker|Carter|1887|pages=152–221}}{{sfn|Cox|2013|pages=101–102}}{{sfn|Massachusetts|1931|pages=649–650}}{{#tag:ref|The inscription on his tombstone also stated he fought at the [[Battle of South Mountain]].|group=note}} His regiment was on the march to the [[Battle of Fredericksburg]] when Pitman was captured by Confederate troops.{{sfn|Vance|Manning|2015b|pages=146–149}}{{sfn|Parker|Carter|1887|pages=152–221}} ===Imprisonment and death=== [[File:LIbby Prison by David Gilmour Blythe, 1863.jpg|thumbnail|right||250px|Depiction of the harsh conditions of [[Libby Prison]] by [[David Gilmour Blythe]], 1863]] The most detailed account of Pitman's final fate in the War came from Robert G. Carter.{{sfn|Vance|Manning|2015b|pages=146–149}} In November 1862, Pitman was captured near [[Warrenton, Virginia|Warrenton Junction]] on the march toward [[Fredericksburg, Virginia]], during the weeks prior to the Battle of Fredericksburg. He had fallen behind the group because his feet had blistered and swollen due to the tightness of "a pair of thin, high-heeled and narrow soled boots" he had purchased. One of his comrades temporarily stayed behind to care for him but later decided to move on with the rest of the camp for fear of disciplinary consequences of falling out without authority. He was urged to move on, but without much success. Pitman's last words to his comrade were, "I will be in camp by night, good by." His fellow soldiers never saw him again and considered him missing. Shortly after he was left, a band of Confederate guerrillas under Colonel [[John S. Mosby]] captured the weary and defenseless soldier without a struggle.{{sfn|Parker|Carter|1887|pages=215–216}}{{sfn|Carter|1897|pages=139–142}}{{sfn|Carter|1913|pages=139–142}} The inscription on his tombstone differs slightly from Carter's account, stating he was captured by [[J. E. B. Stuart]]'s cavalry instead. After Pitman's capture, he was marched to [[Richmond, Virginia|Richmond]] in a weak physical state. He was imprisoned in the Confederate [[Libby Prison]] and [[Belle Isle (Richmond, Virginia)|Belle Isle]], which were notoriously harsh prisons. Pitman's letters home described his place of incarceration as the "Pen"{{#tag:ref|The newspaper ''Hawaiian Gazette'' speculated in 1910 that the "Pen" referred to [[Andersonville National Historic Site|Andersonville Prison]].{{cite news|title=Died in Libby Prison, in Quarrel that Wasn't His'n – Interesting Photograph Recalling the Part Hawaiians Played in the Civil War|newspaper=The Hawaiian Gazette|location=Honolulu|publisher=J. H. Black at the Government Printing Office|date=June 28, 1910|volume=LIII|issue=51|page=3|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83025121/1910-06-28/ed-1/seq-3/|accessdate=August 5, 2015}}|group=note}} where "the filthy meat [was] thrown to them as if they were dogs". The condition of his incarceration including the shortage of food, lack of sanitation, overcrowding and his physical weakness made him susceptible to virulent diseases present in the Confederate prisons.{{sfn|Parker|Carter|1887|pages=215–216}} Carter described how the prisons "wore out the brave spirit".{{sfn|Carter|1897|pages=139–142}}{{sfn|Carter|1913|pages=139–142}} During a prisoner exchange, Pitman was released by the Confederate Army at [[City Point, Virginia]], on December 12, 1862, and then sent to [[Annapolis, Maryland|Annapolis]] [[Parole, Maryland|Parole Camp]].{{sfn|Vance|Manning|2015b|pages=146–149}}{{sfn|Carter|1897|pages=139–142}}{{sfn|Carter|1913|pages=139–142}} Suffering from complications due to the conditions of his imprisonment, he contracted "lung fever", which was perhaps [[pneumonia]].{{sfn|Vance|Manning|2015b|pages=146–149}} Carter wrote later how his friend had "linger[ed] feebly a few weeks, like the flickering of an expiring flame, then quietly pass[ed] away to an eternal life".{{sfn|Carter|1897|pages=139–142}}{{sfn|Carter|1913|pages=139–142}} Pitman died at Parole Camp on February 27, 1863, just weeks short of his eighteenth birthday.{{cite news|title=Death|newspaper=The Pacific Commercial Advertiser|location=Honolulu|publisher=H. M. Whitney|date=May 28, 1863|volume=VII|issue=48|page=3|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015418/1863-05-28/ed-1/seq-3/|accessdate=August 5, 2015}}{{cite news|title=Death – Pitman|newspaper=Evening Saturday Gazette|location=Boston|publisher=William W. Clapp, Jr|date=March 14, 1863|volume=XLIX|issue=11|page=3}}{{sfn|Pitman|1931|page=21}}{{sfn|Hawaiian Mission Children's Society|1863|page=15}} According to historians Anita Manning and Justin Vance, Pitman "has the unfortunate distinction of being the only known Hawaiian or [[Pacific Islander]] to die as a prisoner of war in the Civil War."{{sfn|Vance|Manning|2015b|pages=146–149}} Considering him missing, Pitman's regiment did not discover his final fate until news of his funeral at Roxbury was received in the spring of the following year.{{sfn|Carter|1897|pages=139–142}}{{sfn|Carter|1913|pages=139–142}} His remains were returned to his family in Massachusetts after his death in Parole Camp. Benjamin Pitman, his father, had him buried in a family plot in [[Mount Auburn Cemetery]].{{sfn|Vance|Manning|2015b|pages=146–149}} On one side of the Pitman family grave marker was placed the inscription: [[File:Pitman Family Mausoleum, Mount Auburn Cemetery, 2009.jpg|thumbnail|right||250px|The Pitman Family Mausoleum, at [[Mount Auburn Cemetery]], built by his younger brother Benjamin Keolaokalani Franklin Pitman]]
Timothy Henry Pitman
Born at Hilo, Hawaii
Mar. 18, 1845
Died at Camp Parole
Annapolis, MD, Feb'y 27, 1863

''A member of Co. H, 22nd Regiment
Mass. Vols., was with his Regiment in the
battles of South Mountain, Antietam and
Sharpsburg. Was taken prisoner by Stuart's
cavalry on the march to Fredricksburg;
Imprisoned in Libby Prison, paroled and
sent to Camp Parole, Annapolis, and died in
camp of pneumonia.''{{cite sign|title=Pitman Family Marker|type=|location=Cambridge, Massachusetts|institution=[[Mount Auburn Cemetery]]}}
==Legacy== After his death, the memory of Henry Hoʻolulu Pitman was honored by friends and family members back in Massachusetts and Hawaiʻi. During a return to Hawaiʻi in 1917, his younger brother Benjamin Keolaokalani Franklin Pitman and his wife Almira Hollander Pitman, discovered a grandson of a nephew was named Kealiʻi i Kaua i Pakoma (meaning "Chief that fought the Potomac") in honor of his deceased older brother.{{cite news|title=Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin F. Pitman "At Home"|newspaper=Honolulu Star-Bulletin|location=Honolulu|publisher=Oahu Publications, Inc.|date=February 17, 1917|volume=XXIV|issue=7753|page=9|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82014682/1917-02-17/ed-1/seq-9/|accessdate=August 5, 2015}} Similarly, Henry Hoʻolulu Pitman Beckley, the second son of his Hawaiian first cousin George Charles Moʻoheau Beckley, was also named after him.{{harvnb|McKinzie|1983|page=46}}; {{harvnb|Daughters of the American Revolution|1910|pages=291}} Shortly after his death, Pitman was eulogized back in Hawaiʻi by Martha Ann Chamberlain, Corresponding Secretary of the Hawaiian Mission Children's Society:{{#tag:ref|The three older Pitman children and their half-sister Maria Kinoʻole were lifetime members of the Hawaiian Mission Children's Society since their stepmother Maria Louisa Walsworth Kinney was part of the Twelfth Company of missionaries from the [[American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions]] to arrive in 1848.{{sfn|Hawaiian Mission Children's Society|1863|page=35}}{{sfn|Manning|Vance|2014|pages=161–162}}{{sfn|Hawaiian Mission Children's Society|1901|pages=86, 88}}|group=note}}
Our cousin, Henry Pitman, the first of Hawaii's sons to fall in the war, died at Annapolis Parole Camp, Feb. 27, of lung fever, serving as a soldier in the Union army. His remains were deposited in Mt. Auburn Cemetery, near Boston, Mass. He died in a just cause. Let his memory be embalmed among our band.{{sfn|Hawaiian Mission Children's Society|1863|page=15}}
After the war, the military service of Hawaiians, including Henry Hoʻolulu Pitman, were largely forgotten, disappearing from the collective memories of the American Civil War and the history of Hawaiʻi. However, in recent years, Hawaiian residents and historians and descendants of Hawaiian combatants in the conflict have insisted on the need to remember "our boys from Hawaii". Renewed interest in the stories of these individuals and this particular period of Hawaiian-American history have inspired efforts to preserve the memories of the Hawaiians who served in the war.{{cite news|last=|first=|title=Cousins Department|newspaper=The Friend|location=Honolulu|publisher=|date=August 1, 1917|volume=LXXV|issue=8|page=181|url=http://server.honstudios.com/mhm-friend/cgi-bin/mhm-friend?a=d&d=Friend19170801-01.2.25&cl|accessdate=August 5, 2015}}{{sfn|Vance|Manning|2015c|pages=161–163}} On August 26, 2010, on the anniversary of the signing of the Hawaiian Neutrality Proclamation, a bronze plaque was erected along the memorial pathway at the [[National Memorial Cemetery of the Pacific]] in Honolulu recognizing these "Hawaiʻi Sons of the Civil War", the more than one hundred documented Hawaiians{{#tag:ref|As of 2014, researchers have identified 119 documented Native Hawaiian and Hawaii-born combatants from historical records. The exact number still remains unclear because many Hawaiians enlisted and served under Anglicized names and little is known about them due to the lack of detailed records.{{sfn|Grzyb|2016|pages=127–128}}{{cite news|last=Davis|first=Chelsea|title=Hawaiian Civil War soldier finally recognized|newspaper=Hawaii News Show|date=October 26, 2014|url=http://www.hawaiinewsnow.com/story/27016661/hawaiian-civil-war-solider-finally-recognized|accessdate=August 5, 2015}}; {{cite web|author=Punaboy|title=Hawaiʻi Sons of the Civil War|website=Aloha Valley|date=June 20, 2015|url=http://alohavalley.com/hawaii-sons-of-the-civil-war/|accessdate=August 3, 2015}}|group=note}} who served during the American Civil War for both the Union and the Confederacy. Pitman's great-grandniece Diane Kinoʻole o Liliha Pitman Spieler attended the ceremony. Pitman Spieler stated, "I'm very proud of a young man of his age – he was quite young – who served in the Civil War for his family."{{sfn|Vance|Manning|2015c|pages=161–163}}{{harvnb|Schuessler|2012|page=66}}; {{cite web|title=Memorial Plaque|website=Hawaiʻi Sons of the Civil War|url=http://hawaiisonsofthecivilwar.com/memorial-plaque/|accessdate=June 27, 2014}} In 2013, Todd Ocvirk, Nanette Napoleon, Justin Vance, Anita Manning and others began the process of creating a historical [[documentary film|documentary]] about the individual experiences and stories of Hawaii-born soldiers and sailors of the American Civil War, including Pitman, [[Samuel C. Armstrong]], [[Nathaniel Bright Emerson]], [[James Wood Bush]], [[J. R. Kealoha]] and many other unnamed combatants of both the Union and the Confederacy.{{cite news|last=Murray|first=Anthony|title=Sons Of The Civil War|newspaper=Midweek Kauai|location=Honolulu|publisher=Oahu Publications, Inc.|date=July 2, 2013|url=http://www.midweekkauai.com/featured/sons-of-the-civil-war/|accessdate=August 5, 2015}}; {{cite news|last=Sodetani|first=Naomi|title=Sons of the Civil War|newspaper=Ka Wai Ola|location=Honolulu|publisher=Office of Hawaiian Affairs|date=February 2013|volume=30|number=2|page=15|url=http://issuu.com/kawaiola/docs/kwo0213_web/15|accessdate=August 5, 2015}}; {{cite web|last=Ocvirk|first=Todd|title=Hawaii Sons of the Civil War – A Documentary Film|website=Indiegogo|date=July 31, 2013|url=https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/hawaii-sons-of-the-civil-war-a-documentary-film#/|accessdate=August 3, 2015}}; {{cite news|last=Tanaka|first=Chris|title=Hawaii's little known role in the Civil War|newspaper=Hawaii News Now|location=Honolulu|date=September 20, 2013|url=http://www.hawaiinewsnow.com/story/23490890/hawaii-and-the-civil-war|accessdate=August 5, 2015}} In 2014, [[Maui]]-based author Wayne Moniz wrote a fictionalized story based on the lives and Civil War service of Hawaiian soldiers like Henry Hoʻolulu Pitman in his book ''Pukoko: A Hawaiian in the American Civil War''.{{cite news|last=Pignataro|first=Anthony|title=Talking story with author Wayne Moniz about Hawaii's hidden Civil War history|newspaper=MauiTime|location=Wailuku|publisher=MauiTime Productions|date=March 18, 2015|url=http://mauitime.com/culture/history/talking-story-with-author-wayne-moniz-about-hawaiis-hidden-civil-war-history/|accessdate=August 5, 2015}} In 2015, the sesquicentennial of the end of the war, the [[National Park Service]] released a publication titled ''Asians and Pacific Islanders and the Civil War'' about the service of the large number of combatants of Asian and Pacific Islander descent who fought during the war.
